trans-unit.source: A universal function (or ufunc for short) is a function that operates on n-dimensional arrays in an element-by-element fashion, supporting array broadcasting. The for-loops that are involved are fully implemented in C diminishing the overhead of the Python interpreter.
trans-unit.target: A universal function (or ufunc for short) is a function that operates on n-dimensional arrays in an element-by-element fashion, supporting array broadcasting. The for-loops that are involved are fully implemented in C diminishing the overhead of the Python interpreter.

trans-unit.source: Both Shapely and PyGEOS are exposing the functionality of the GEOS C++ library to Python. While Shapely only deals with single geometries, PyGEOS provides vectorized functions to work with arrays of geometries, giving better performance and convenience for such usecases.
trans-unit.target: Both Shapely and PyGEOS are exposing the functionality of the GEOS C++ library to Python. While Shapely only deals with single geometries, PyGEOS provides vectorized functions to work with arrays of geometries, giving better performance and convenience for such usecases.

trans-unit.source: Note: PyGEOS is a very young package. While the available functionality should be stable and working correctly, it’s still possible that APIs change in upcoming releases. But we would love for you to try it out, give feedback or contribute!
trans-unit.target: Note: PyGEOS is a very young package. While the available functionality should be stable and working correctly, it’s still possible that APIs change in upcoming releases. But we would love for you to try it out, give feedback or contribute!

trans-unit.source: PyGEOS is a C/Python library with vectorized geometry functions. The geometry operations are done in the open-source geometry library GEOS. PyGEOS wraps these operations in NumPy ufuncs providing a performance improvement when operating on arrays of geometries.
trans-unit.target: PyGEOS is a C/Python library with vectorized geometry functions. The geometry operations are done in the open-source geometry library GEOS. PyGEOS wraps these operations in NumPy ufuncs providing a performance improvement when operating on arrays of geometries.

trans-unit.source: PyGEOS is licensed under BSD 3-Clause license. Copyright (c) 2019, Casper van der Wel. GEOS is available under the terms of ​GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL) 2.1 at https://trac.osgeo.org/geos.
trans-unit.target: PyGEOS is licensed under BSD 3-Clause license. Copyright (c) 2019, Casper van der Wel. GEOS is available under the terms of ​GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL) 2.1 at https://trac.osgeo.org/geos.

trans-unit.source: Pygeos requires the presence of NumPy and GEOS >= 3.5. It is recommended to install these using Anaconda from the conda-forge channel (which provides pre-compiled binaries):
trans-unit.target: Pygeos requires the presence of NumPy and GEOS >= 3.5. It is recommended to install these using Anaconda from the conda-forge channel (which provides pre-compiled binaries):

trans-unit.source: There is still discussion of integrating PyGEOS into Shapely (https://github.com/Toblerity/Shapely/issues/782), but for now PyGEOS is developed as a separate project.
trans-unit.target: There is still discussion of integrating PyGEOS into Shapely (https://github.com/Toblerity/Shapely/issues/782), but for now PyGEOS is developed as a separate project.

trans-unit.source: object. This keeps the python interpreter out of the ufunc inner loop. The Geometry object keeps track of the underlying GEOSGeometry and allows the python garbage collector to free memory when it is not used anymore.
trans-unit.target: object. This keeps the python interpreter out of the ufunc inner loop. The Geometry object keeps track of the underlying GEOSGeometry and allows the python garbage collector to free memory when it is not used anymore.
